results.name: Product of run lengths in binary representation of n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..8192
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
example: a(56) = 9, because 56 in binary is written 111000 giving the run lengths 3,3 and 3x3 = 9.
a(99) = 12, because 99 in binary is written 1100011 giving the run lengths 2,3,2, and 2x3x2 = 12.
program: (define (binexp->runcount1list n) (if (zero? n) (list) (let loop ((n n) (rc (list)) (count 0) (prev-bit (modulo n 2))) (if (zero? n) (cons count rc) (if (eq? (modulo n 2) prev-bit) (loop (floor->exact (/ n 2)) rc (1+ count) (modulo n 2)) (loop (floor->exact (/ n 2)) (cons count rc) 1 (modulo n 2)))))))
a167489 = product . map length . group . a030308_row
'''Product of run lengths in binary representation of n.'''
# _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 24 2013 (Cf. Python program for A227184).
(PARI) a(n) = {my(p=1, b=n%2, i=0); while(n!=0, n=n>>1; i=i+1; if((n%2)!=b, p=p*i; i=0; b=n%2)); p} \\ _Indranil Ghosh_, Apr 17 2017, after the Python Program by _Antti Karttunen_
xref: Row products of A101211 and A227736 (for n > 0).
Cf. A167490 (smallest number with binary run length product = n).
Cf. A167491 (members of A167490 sorted in ascending order).
Differs from similar A284579 for the first time at n=56, where a(56) = 9, while A284579(56) = 5.
results.author: _Andrew Weimholt_, Nov 05 2009
